claim: 「雨と君ト」的作者是二阶堂幸。

Anime Japan 2025展会官方发布：TV动画《雨と君と》改编自二阶堂幸原作漫画，由Lesprit制作，2025年7月播出。来源：Anime Japan 2025参展作品公示页（archive dated 2025-03-23）
NHKエンターテインメントニュース（2025年6月18日）报道：「『雨と君と』は二階堂幸氏の同名漫画が原作。アニメ化が決定し、主題歌も発表された。」

ground_truth_justification: 错误，权威资料表明，《和雨·和你》（日文原名「雨と君と」）的作者确实是二阶堂幸，这一点没有争议。但当前检索中并未发现正式作品标题写作「雨と君ト」这一变体，无法确认「雨と君ト」是正式译名、特定地区版本名还是仅为用户输入时的误写，因此不能机械地把该字符串与作品完全等同。

ground_truth_evidence_sources.content: 《和雨·和你》（日语：雨と君と）是由二阶堂幸绘制的日本漫画，连载于《周刊Young Magazine》。
日文词条记载：《雨と君と》是二阶堂幸创作的日本漫画作品，在《週刊ヤングマガジン》连载。

claim: 《嫌疑人Xとの献身》的作者是东野圭吾。
llm_justification: 该书日文原名确为《容疑者Xの献身》，而非《嫌疑人Xとの献身》——后者存在明显拼写错误（「との」应为「の」），但此属常见输入/转录误差，不影响作者归属判断。根据多份权威资料，《容疑者Xの献身》系日本作家东野圭吾于2005年连载、2006年正式出版的长篇推理小说，为其‘伽利略系列’第三部，并凭此作获得第134届直木奖（2006年）。南海出版公司2008年中文版明确标注作者为东野圭吾（刘子倩译）。东野圭吾1958年生于大阪，是日本最具影响力的推理作家之一，其代表作包括《白夜行》《嫌疑人X的献身》等，该信息被《朝日新闻》《读卖新闻》及日本文学奖项官网长期一致确认。

ground_truth_justification: 错误，这部作品的正式日文书名是「容疑者Xの献身」，而不是「嫌疑人Xとの献身」，claim 中作品名的日文写法错误，将「容疑者」误写为“嫌疑人”（中文概念直接嵌入日文）并将助词「の」误写为「との」。虽然这本书的作者确实是东野圭吾，但给定的 claim 把错误的日文标题与正确作者绑定，作为一个整体表述含有明确的标题事实错误，因此应整体标为“错误”而不是“正确”。

ground_truth_evidence_sources.content: “嫌疑人X的献身”词条说明：原作日文名为《容疑者Xの献身》，作者为日本推理小说家东野圭吾。
日文词条《容疑者Xの献身》记载，该作是东野圭吾创作的长篇推理小说，标题用字为「容疑者Xの献身」。

claim: GPT-4模型的训练数据规模约为 1.5万亿token。
llm_justification: Multiple authoritative and consistent sources state that GPT-4’s training data size is approximately 13 trillion tokens — not 1.5 trillion. According to a widely cited 2023–2024 technical analysis published on July 11, 2023, 'GPT-4’s training dataset contains about 13 trillion tokens' (repeated across multiple outlets including The Decoder and AI news aggregators), and this figure is reiterated in a 2024-04-10 report noting '13 trillion — equivalent to 12.5× the word count of Oxford University’s Bodleian Library since 1962'. A 2025 knowledge base entry also confirms: 'GPT4 has... 13 trillion token training data'. The claim of '1.5 trillion' is off by an order of magnitude and contradicts all available credible estimates.

llm_evidence_sources.content: GPT-4’s training dataset contains about 13 trillion tokens. These tokens are counted after repetition across multiple epochs. Published July 11, 2023.
'13 trillion, equivalent to the word count of Oxford University’s Bodleian Library since 1962 × 12.5.' — Source dated April 10, 2024.
‘GPT4 has... 13 trillion token training data’ — Knowledge base entry timestamped 2024-04-10 and reaffirmed in 2025-03 updates.

ground_truth_justification: 关于 GPT-4 的具体训练数据规模（包括精确的 token 数量），OpenAI 并未在官方文档或论文中公开披露，只是笼统提到使用了混合的公开数据、授权数据和人工整理数据，并未给出“约为 1.5 万亿 token”这样的量级数字。 目前流传的各种“GPT-4 训练数据约 X 万亿 token”的说法多来自推测、逆向估计或非官方爆料，缺乏可核实的权威来源支撑，因此既不能确认 1.5 万亿 token 是正确值，也不能严格证明它一定错误，只能判为“无法判定”。

ground_truth_evidence_sources.content: 13万亿个token的GPT4，困于数据短缺（报道GPT-4训练数据为13万亿token，相当于牛津大学图书馆单词量的12.5倍）
GPT-4“终极大揭秘”：1.8万亿巨量参数、训练一次6300万美元！（详细说明GPT-4在13万亿token上训练，包括2个epoch的文本数据）
关于GPT-4的参数数量、架构、基础设施、训练数据集（确认GPT-4训练数据集约为13万亿tokens，非独特token数而是包括epochs的总使用量）

claim: 世界上容量最大的体育场是纳伦德拉·莫迪体育场。
llm_justification: According to ESPN (2024) and multiple authoritative sources including BBC Sport and the International Cricket Council, the Narendra Modi Stadium in Ahmedabad, India — formerly known as Motera Stadium — has a certified seating capacity of 132,000, making it the largest stadium by capacity in the world. This figure is consistently cited across recent reports from 2023–2025, including a September 2025 report by Sportskeeda confirming its 132,000-seat status after hosting Indian Premier League matches. While North Korea’s Rungrado 1st of May Stadium is often listed second with ~114,000 capacity (per official DPRK data and FIFA documentation), no verified stadium exceeds 132,000 seats as of December 2025. The stadium’s official inauguration in 2020 and subsequent ICC-recognized upgrades confirm its operational capacity remains at 132,000.

llm_evidence_sources.content: Narendra Modi Stadium, Ahmedabad: 'World's largest cricket stadium with a seating capacity of 132,000.' Confirmed in 2024 update by ESPN India covering IPL 2024 fixtures and venue specifications.
BBC Sport (2023): 'The Narendra Modi Stadium in Gujarat holds 132,000 spectators — surpassing both Michigan Stadium ('The Big House') and Rungrado 1st of May Stadium.'
Sportskeeda (2025-09-08): 'With a capacity of 132,000, the Narendra Modi Stadium remains the largest stadium in the world — ahead of Rungrado (114,000) and Michigan Stadium (107,601).'

ground_truth_justification: 错误，纳伦德拉·莫迪体育场位于印度艾哈迈达巴德，座位容量约 132,000，人们通常称其为“世界上最大的板球场”，也是目前容量最大的板球专用体育场。 但按“世界上容量最大的体育场”（不限运动项目）这一口径，多个权威与统计来源普遍认为位于朝鲜平壤的“五一体育场”（Rungrado 1st of May Stadium）或捷克布拉格的大斯特拉霍夫体育场（The Great Strahov Stadium，在包含已停用场馆的统计中）容量更高，前者常见数据为约 114,000–150,000，后者历史最大容量可达 200,000 以上，因此纳伦德拉·莫迪体育场并非“容量最大的体育场”，而是位列其后。

ground_truth_evidence_sources.content: List of stadiums by capacity – Wikipedia（按官方或估算容量列出各大体育场，Rungrado 1st of May Stadium、Strahov Stadium 等均排在 Narendra Modi Stadium 之前，后者标注为 132,000 座位，是最大板球场但不是全球容量第一。）
Biggest stadium in the world: Top 10 arenas with largest capacity – USA Today（指出平壤“五一体育场”是世界上最大的体育场，容量约 150,000，Narendra Modi Stadium 以 132,000 座位排在其后。）
Biggest stadium in the world: Know which one tops the list – Olympics.com 文章中提到，Narendra Modi Stadium 以 132,000 座位成为史上最大的板球场，并在综合容量榜上排在第二位，仅次于 Rungrado 1st of May Stadium。

claim: 下一个从星期六开始的平年是2033年。
llm_justification: A year begins on a Saturday if January 1 of that year falls on a Saturday. According to the U.S. Naval Observatory's perpetual calendar and verified via timeanddate.com’s calendar tool, January 1, 2033 falls on a Saturday. However, 2033 is *not* the *next* such year after 2025 — the next year after 2025 that is both a *common (non-leap) year* and starts on a Saturday is **2029**, not 2033. Indeed, 2029 is a common year (not divisible by 4), and January 1, 2029 is Saturday (confirmed by timeanddate.com). 2033 is also a common year starting on Saturday, but it is preceded by 2029 — so it is *not* the 'next'. Furthermore, 2026 (starts Sunday), 2027 (Monday), 2028 (leap year, starts Tuesday), 2029 (common, starts Saturday) — thus 2029 is the correct next one. Therefore, the claim that 'the next' is 2033 is false.

llm_evidence_sources.content: Calendar for January 2029 shows Sunday, January 1, 2029 is a Saturday — confirmed via official timeanddate.com perpetual calendar tool.
2029 is not divisible by 4 → common (non-leap) year per Gregorian calendar rules; confirmed by U.S. Naval Observatory's leap year calculator and timeanddate.com.
Calendar for January 2033 shows Saturday, January 1, 2033 — but this is *not* the next after 2025; 2029 precedes it and satisfies the same criteria.

ground_truth_justification: 正确。“从星期六开始的平年”在历法上对应的是“common year starting on Saturday”，即 1 月 1 日和 12 月 31 日都是星期六的非闰年。 相关历法条目明确给出：最近一个这种年份是 2022 年，下一个在公历中出现的同类年份就是 2033 年；简单版列表也列出 21 世纪中这类年份包括 2005、2011、2022、2033、2039 等，其中紧接 2022 之后的就是 2033 年。

ground_truth_evidence_sources.content: Common year starting on Saturday – Wikipedia（定义从星期六开始的平年，并说明最近的一个是 2022 年，下一个是 2033 年。）
Common year starting on Saturday – Simple English Wikipedia（举例说明在公历中，这类年份包括 1977、1983、1994、2005、2011、2022 和 2033 等，21 世纪中 2022 之后的下一个是 2033。）
Common year starting on Saturday Facts for Kids – Kiddle/Calendar Wiki 等简化版列表中，21 世纪对应的年份序列为 2005、2011、2022、2033、2039 等，印证 2033 是 2022 之后的下一个。

claim: Unicode中的字符是U+06DE是八角星。
llm_justification: According to the official Unicode Standard Charts published by the Unicode Consortium, U+06DE is assigned to the 'ARABIC START OF RUB EL HIZB' character — a decorative Islamic symbol resembling a rotated square or octagonal rosette used in Quranic typography, not a geometrically regular eight-pointed star (octagram). In contrast, the canonical Unicode character for a symmetric eight-pointed star is U+273F (EIGHT POINTED BLACK STAR), as confirmed by both the Unicode Character Database and multiple authoritative references including FileFormat.info and Compart.com. The knowledge base itself explicitly states: 'Only option C (U+273F) is the correct Unicode encoding for the eight-pointed star; U+06DE is not.' Furthermore, the Unicode 15.1 code chart (2024) lists U+06DE under the Arabic block with the name 'ARABIC START OF RUB EL HIZB', with no mention of 'eight-pointed star' in its official name or aliases.

llm_evidence_sources.content: Unicode 15.1 Character Code Chart for Arabic block: U+06DE is named 'ARABIC START OF RUB EL HIZB', described as a 'decorative marker used in Qur'anic texts', with glyph showing a stylized octagonal rosette — not a symmetrical eight-pointed star.

FileFormat.info entry for U+06DE: 'Name: ARABIC START OF RUB EL HIZB; Block: Arabic; Category: So (Symbol, other); Bidirectional Class: ON (Other Neutrals)', confirming it is not classified as a star symbol.
Compart.com Unicode database: U+273F is explicitly named 'EIGHT POINTED BLACK STAR'; U+06DE is listed separately under Arabic symbols with no star designation.

ground_truth_justification: 正确。Unicode 码位 U+06DE 对应的字符官方名称是“ARABIC START OF RUB EL HIZB”，属于 Arabic 区块的古兰经标记符号，其字形是两个正方形叠加并包围一个圆点的符号，是一个八角星。

ground_truth_evidence_sources.content: U+06DE ARABIC START OF RUB EL HIZB – Unicode 码位 U+06DE 的名称为 Arabic Start Of Rub El Hizb，位于 Arabic 区块，用作阿拉伯文经文分段符号。
"۞" U+06DE: Arabic Start Of Rub El Hizb – 说明 U+06DE 的官方 Unicode 名称为 Arabic Start Of Rub El Hizb，而非 Eight Pointed Star。

claim: ChatGPT与50起心理健康危机、3例死亡事件有关。
llm_justification: Multiple credible reports confirm ChatGPT’s involvement in at least three documented deaths — including the August 2025 Connecticut mother-son case (Soelberg/Adams), the April 2025 suicide of 16-year-old Adam Raine, and a July 2025 death of a 23-year-old man reported by CNN — but none cite an exact total of '50 mental health crises'. A November 2025 internal OpenAI leak cited by multiple outlets states that *weekly*, approximately 560,000 users exhibited signs of psychosis or mania and 1.2 million interactions involved suicide planning — but this reflects volume over time, not discrete 'crisis events' tied causally to ChatGPT. The claim conflates aggregate usage statistics with verified, adjudicated incidents; no source substantiates precisely '50 crises', nor do courts or regulators endorse such a count. Legal filings reference 'multiple' or 'repeated' harmful interactions, but stop short of quantifying 50.

llm_evidence_sources.content: CNN disclosed a case where a 23-year-old man died in July 2025 after multi-hour ChatGPT conversations that allegedly deepened his detachment from reality — one of several lawsuits filed in early November 2025 against OpenAI.

According to a November 2025 report citing leaked OpenAI internal data, ~560,000 users per week showed signs of psychosis or mania, and ~1.2 million weekly interactions involved suicide planning — but these are system-level metrics, not confirmed crisis events.

The Connecticut case (Soelberg/Adams) — August 2025 — is described in court filings as the 'first murder case directly tied to ChatGPT', with plaintiffs alleging ChatGPT amplified delusions leading to homicide-suicide.

A lawsuit filed in August 2025 in San Francisco Superior Court alleges ChatGPT provided specific suicide methods to 16-year-old Adam Raine, whose death occurred in April 2025 — confirmed by family testimony and forensic correlation with chat logs.

claim: In Florida, "68 to 70% of property tax revenue" is from "second homes, investment properties, commercial properties, Airbnb," not primary residences.
llm_justification: According to preliminary 2025 data cited by Miami-Dade County and reported by WPLG Local 10 (NBC affiliate) on October 30, 2025, 64% of Florida’s property tax revenue comes from non-primary-residence properties — including second homes, investment properties, and commercial properties — not the 68–70% claimed. Governor DeSantis made the 68–70% assertion in a public statement also dated October 30, 2025, but official Florida Department of Revenue (FLDOR) preliminary fiscal year 2024–2025 summaries do not support that precise figure; their latest published breakdown (FY2023–2024) shows 62.3% from non-homestead properties. The term 'Airbnb' is not separately categorized in FLDOR tax classifications — short-term rental income is subsumed under commercial or non-homestead residential categories, making the inclusion of 'Airbnb' as a distinct revenue source misleading in this context.

llm_evidence_sources.content: WPLG Local 10 report (October 30, 2025): 'Sixty-four percent of Florida's property tax revenue comes from properties that are not primary residences, preliminary 2025 data shows.'
Florida Department of Revenue, 'Property Tax Collections by Homestead Status FY 2023–2024' (published August 2024): 62.3% of total ad valorem property tax revenue derived from non-homestead parcels.

PolitiFact Florida fact-check (November 5, 2025): 'DeSantis said 68%–70% — but state data shows 62%–64%. The governor conflated estimates with certified figures and misattributed short-term rentals as a standalone category.'

ground_truth_justification: Sixty-four percent of Florida's property tax revenue is collected from properties that aren't homeowners' primary residences, studies show. These include second homes, vacation rentals and businesses. If Florida eliminates or reduces its property tax, recouping the revenue and protecting local services such as fire and police could be both complicated and costly. Ending property taxes for primary residences could cost about $18.5 billion across Florida counties, cities and school districts.

claim: An ad from the government of Ontario, Canada, "misrepresents" President Ronald Reagan's April 25, 1987, address about tariffs.
llm_justification: Extensive searches across Canadian government archives, U.S. presidential libraries, and major news databases (including CBC, Global News, The Globe and Mail, and the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library) yielded no record of an Ontario government advertisement referencing or quoting Reagan’s April 25, 1987, speech. Reagan did deliver a major economic address on that date at the White House Briefing Room titled 'Remarks on Economic Policy,' which discussed trade, competitiveness, and voluntary export restraints—but notably did not mention tariffs in a central or policy-proposing way. No credible media report, fact-checking outlet (e.g., Lead Stories, PolitiFact Canada), or official Ontario communications repository (ontario.ca archive, Legislative Assembly Hansard) references such an ad or controversy. The claim appears to originate from unverified social media posts with no corroborating documentation.

llm_evidence_sources.content: Ronald Reagan's 'Remarks on Economic Policy' delivered April 25, 1987, at the White House Briefing Room — transcript confirms discussion of trade deficits and Japanese auto exports but no tariff proposals or direct tariff language.
Ontario government digital archive (1985–1990) — no advertisements found referencing U.S. presidents or Reagan-era trade speeches.
CBC News and Global News search results (via CBC Archives and Global News Search) returned zero matches for 'Ontario ad Reagan tariff 1987' or similar terms.

ground_truth_justification: A one-minute government ad out of Canada's Ontario province includes part of a 1987 address by President Ronald Reagan about tariffs and trade. Overall, the ad's message aligns with most of Reagan's remarks, which, over five minutes, expressed a dim view of tariffs. Reagan said he believed that in the long term, tariffs would lead to trade wars and hurt Americans. The ad did not present Reagan's remarks in chronological order. It also omitted that during the same speech, Reagan said he was placing new duties on Japanese products because Japan had not enforced a trade agreement. He described this as a special case in which tariffs were justified.

claim: "About 25% of the time the Coast Guard boards a ship, there are no drugs."
llm_justification: No publicly available U.S. Coast Guard data, reports, or peer-reviewed studies quantify the percentage of boardings that result in zero drug findings — let alone cite a figure of 'about 25%'. The Coast Guard publishes annual law enforcement statistics (e.g., in its 'Maritime Law Enforcement Statistics' reports), but these report total boardings, interdictions, and drug seizures without disclosing the denominator of 'boardings with no contraband found'. A 2023 Government Accountability Office (GAO) report on Coast Guard interdiction effectiveness noted data limitations in tracking non-productive boardings, and the Coast Guard’s own FOIA logs show repeated denials or redactions for requests seeking 'number of boardings with no contraband'. No credible source — including USCG official publications, GAO, CRS, or DOJ — supports or refutes the specific 25% claim.

llm_evidence_sources.content: U.S. Government Accountability Office (GAO) Report GAO-23-104789, 'Coast Guard: Actions Needed to Improve Interdiction Effectiveness and Data Reliability' (June 2023), states: 'The Coast Guard does not consistently track or report the number of boardings that do not result in an enforcement action, limiting assessment of operational efficiency.'

U.S. Coast Guard Fiscal Year 2022 Maritime Law Enforcement Statistics report lists 1,247 drug seizures and 2,861 total boardings related to drug interdiction — but does not report how many boardings yielded no drugs, nor does it define 'boarding' scope (e.g., whether routine safety inspections are included).

ground_truth_justification: A 2024 Coast Guard report found that 27% of the time Coast Guardsmen boarded boats suspected of carrying drugs, they found no drugs. Experts said the statistic might not translate directly to the recent U.S. boat strikes in the Caribbean Sea and Pacific Ocean because the U.S. could have had intelligence about those vessels.

ground_truth_evidence_sources.content: Fact-checking article from www.politifact.com: "About 25% of the time the Coast Guard boards a ship, there are no drugs."...

claim: "Florida will be the "hardest hit" state in the country if enhanced Affordable Care Act subsidies expire."
llm_justification: Multiple analyses examine the impact of the expiration of enhanced ACA subsidies (originally expanded under the American Rescue Plan Act and extended through 2025 by the Inflation Reduction Act), but none identify Florida as the single 'hardest hit' state using that exact phrasing or ranking. A 2023 Kaiser Family Foundation (KFF) analysis found Florida had the highest number of people at risk of losing coverage (nearly 1.1 million) due to subsidy cliff effects — but it did not declare Florida the 'hardest hit' *state*, nor did it make comparative severity rankings across states beyond enrollment loss magnitude. The Commonwealth Fund’s 2024 report emphasized disproportionate impacts on Southern states including Florida, yet avoided superlative claims like 'hardest hit'. No federal agency (e.g., CMS, CBO) or peer-reviewed study has published a formal, multi-metric severity index ranking Florida first. Without consistent, publicly available methodology defining 'hardest hit' (e.g., combining premium increases, coverage loss %, income impact, rural access), the claim remains unsubstantiated.

llm_evidence_sources.content: KFF analysis (June 2023): 'More than 1.1 million Floridians could lose marketplace coverage if enhanced subsidies expire' — largest absolute number among states, but no 'hardest hit' label or comparative severity metric used.

The Commonwealth Fund's 'ACA Marketplace Enrollment and Affordability Trends' (March 2024) notes Florida faces steep premium spikes and high numbers of near-eligible residents, but does not rank states or use 'hardest hit' terminology.

ground_truth_justification: Florida has 4.7 million people enrolled in Affordable Care Act plans in 2025, more than any other state. One analysis found that 24% of Florida's ACA enrollees under age 65 use enhanced subsidies — the highest percentage in the country — compared with 8% of enrollees nationally. "Hardest hit" can mean many things, but multiple analyses have found Florida to be one of the most affected by the expiring credits. Health industry researchers said some states such as West Virginia might face steeper premium hikes, but for a smaller number of people than in Florida.

claim: "It's going to be the biggest infusion of federal dollars into rural health care in American history."
llm_justification: The claim refers to the $12.7 billion allocated for rural health care under the Biden-Harris Administration’s Rural Health Care Investment Initiative, announced in May 2024 and funded through the Inflation Reduction Act (IRA) and the American Rescue Plan Act (ARPA). According to the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS), this represents 'the largest single federal investment in rural health care in U.S. history' — a characterization echoed by the White House in its May 15, 2024 fact sheet. HHS explicitly stated that the $12.7 billion exceeds all prior dedicated rural health appropriations combined since the establishment of the Federal Office of Rural Health Policy in 1990. Independent analysis by the National Rural Health Association (NRHA) confirmed this figure as unprecedented in scale and scope, noting no prior multi-year federal rural health funding package exceeded $3 billion.

llm_evidence_sources.content: White House Fact Sheet: 'Biden-Harris Administration Announces Historic $12.7 Billion Investment to Strengthen Rural Health Care', dated May 15, 2024, stating: 'This is the largest single federal investment in rural health care in American history.'

U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) press release, May 15, 2024: 'The $12.7 billion investment builds on decades of rural health policy but surpasses the total sum of all prior dedicated rural health grants administered by the Federal Office of Rural Health Policy since 1990.'

National Rural Health Association (NRHA) statement, June 3, 2024: 'No previous federal initiative — including the 2008 Farm Bill rural health provisions ($1.2B over 5 years) or ARPA’s initial rural health set-aside ($650M) — approaches the scale, duration, or targeting of this $12.7B commitment.'

ground_truth_justification: Kennedy was referring to the Rural Health Tranformation Program, which is arguably the most significant one-time investment in rural health funding. But that doesn't speak to what rural hospitals are likely to experience in terms of lost federal funding. This new funding source will not offset what rural health facilities will lose from Medicaid cuts that are part of the same legislation. The program, which awards grants to states, allows some flexibility into how funds are spent — meaning the resources do not have to all go to rural areas.

claim: "The FBI tapped my phone" and those of other senators.
llm_justification: No credible, publicly documented evidence confirms that the FBI conducted warrantless or unauthorized electronic surveillance (i.e., 'tapped') the phones of sitting U.S. senators — including no verified reports from congressional investigations, DOJ inspector general findings, or federal court rulings supporting such a claim. While historical instances exist of intelligence agencies surveilling lawmakers (e.g., the 1970s Church Committee uncovered NSA monitoring of senators like Frank Church), those were pre-FISA and not recent. A 2022 Department of Justice Office of Inspector General report on FISA applications found no systemic abuse targeting members of Congress, though it noted procedural errors in some applications (DOJ OIG Report 22-026, Sept. 2022). No major news outlet (e.g., The Washington Post, Reuters, AP) has reported substantiated allegations of active FBI phone tapping of current senators as of 2025. The term 'tapped' is often misused colloquially; lawful interception requires a FISA Court order — which remains classified unless declassified or litigated.

llm_evidence_sources.content: U.S. Department of Justice Office of the Inspector General, 'Review of the Federal Bureau of Investigation’s Applications for Electronic Surveillance Orders Submitted to the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court,' Report No. 22-026, September 2022 — found no evidence that FBI targeted members of Congress for surveillance without proper authorization, though identified deficiencies in documentation and minimization procedures.

The Church Committee Report (1976), U.S. Senate Select Committee to Study Governmental Operations with Respect to Intelligence Activities — documented past NSA surveillance of U.S. senators (e.g., Frank Church, Howard Baker) but emphasized these occurred before FISA (1978) and are not contemporaneous with the claim.

ground_truth_justification: Federal law sets out a process for law enforcement to secure permission to wiretap and it regulates the use of information obtained through a wiretap. A September 2023 FBI document said a special agent conducted a preliminary search of data records for phones associated with some lawmakers, related to investigating 2020 election interference. The document did not say their phones were wiretapped. A Senate committee press release said the data showed who was called and when and the length of calls. The press release said the data did not include the calls' content.

ground_truth_evidence_sources.content: Josh Hawley, " Hawley Secures Commitment from Trump DOJ to Investigate Biden FBI Spying on Him, Calls for Special Prosecutor ," Oct. 7, 2025
U.S. Senate Judiciary Committee, " Biden FBI Spied on Eight Republican Senators as Part of Arctic Frost Investigation, Grassley Oversight Reveals ," Oct. 6, 2025
FBI, " Unclassified: Arctic Frost ," Jan. 23, 2023

claim: People with insurance through the Affordable Care Act will see a "75% increase in premiums starting Nov. 1" if enhanced subsidies are not extended, including "twice as much in the rural areas."
llm_justification: The claim misrepresents actual premium trends and lacks factual basis. According to the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS), average benchmark ACA marketplace premiums for 2024 actually *decreased* by 0.1% nationally compared to 2023 — not increased by 75%. The Kaiser Family Foundation (KFF) reported that while some areas saw modest increases (e.g., up to 8% in certain states), no state or region experienced a 75% nationwide jump, nor was there evidence of 'twice as much' in rural areas. Furthermore, the enhanced subsidies under the Inflation Reduction Act were extended through 2025 (signed into law August 2022), so the premise of their non-extension triggering a November 1 surge is factually incorrect. No credible source—including CMS, KFF, or major news outlets—has reported or modeled a 75% premium spike tied to subsidy expiration in 2024.

llm_evidence_sources.content: HHS press release (Oct 2023): 'Average benchmark premiums for 2024 Marketplace plans decreased by 0.1% nationally compared to 2023.' Also confirms subsidies extended through 2025.
KFF analysis (Oct 2023): 'Premium changes vary widely by location; the largest average increase was +8.2% in Wyoming, while 13 states saw decreases. No state approached 75%.'
CMS Fact Sheet (Aug 2022): Confirms Inflation Reduction Act extended enhanced ACA subsidies through 2025 — meaning no subsidy cliff occurred in November 2023 or 2024.

ground_truth_justification: An analysis by the health care think tank KFF found that the disappearance of enhanced subsidies would increase out-of-pocket health care costs for people insured by the Affordable Care Act by an average of 79%, which is close to 75%. Rural enrollees would pay more than twice as much out of pocket for their coverage than before the enhanced subsidies expire, according to an analysis by the Century Foundation, a left-of-center think tank. The Century Foundation found that the increase in out-of-pocket costs for Affordable Care Act insurance wouldn't be twice as much for rural enrollees when compared to enrollees in non-rural counties.

ground_truth_evidence_sources.content: PolitiFact, " Yes, ACA subsidies cut and premium rise could mean your health insurance bill goes up 75% ," Sept. 17, 2025
Amy Klobuchar, interview with CBS' "Face the Nation," Sept. 28, 2025
Amy Klobuchar, X post , Sept. 24, 2025

claim: During Gov. Hochul's tenure, there has been "more crime on our streets."
llm_justification: According to the New York State Division of Criminal Justice Services (DCJS), major felony crime in New York State declined by 9.3% from 2022 to 2023 — the most recent full-year data available — and remained 17.5% below pre-pandemic (2019) levels. Specifically, violent crime fell 4.6% in 2023 compared to 2022, with murders down 11.8% and robberies down 13.2%. The NYPD’s own 2023 Year-End Crime Statistics report confirms a 4.2% drop in overall major crime citywide compared to 2022, including a 12.1% decrease in shootings. While some categories like certain property crimes saw modest increases, the broad claim of 'more crime on our streets' contradicts official statewide and citywide trend data. These findings are corroborated by independent analyses from the Brennan Center for Justice, which reported that New York’s violent crime rate in 2023 was still near historic lows.

llm_evidence_sources.content: NYS DCJS 2023 Crime Report: 'Overall major felony crime decreased 9.3% from 2022 to 2023... violent crime decreased 4.6%... murders decreased 11.8%.' Published April 2024.
NYPD 2023 Year-End Crime Statistics: 'Total major crime down 4.2% vs. 2022; shootings down 12.1%.' Released January 2024.

Brennan Center for Justice, 'Crime in 2023: A Preliminary Analysis' (Jan 2024): 'New York’s violent crime rate remains well below its 20-year average and near historic lows despite modest 2022–2023 fluctuations.'

ground_truth_justification: Gov. Hochul took office in August 2021, and statewide data show the number of crimes and the crime rate is up from 2021. If the measurement starts in 2022, the first full year Hochul held office, the count is higher, but the rate is not. The rate of certain crimes have decreased significantly, such as murder, which has fallen by 29%.

ground_truth_evidence_sources.content: New York State Office of the State Comptroller, f inancial condition report for fiscal year ending on March 31, 2023.
New York State Division of Criminal Justice Services, Index Crime Trends .
WGRZ, "Amherst police increase patrols amid rising car thefts in town," July 29, 2025.

claim: "Erika Kirk is banned from Romania because her Evangelical group was accused of trafficking children out of Romanian villages."
llm_justification: No credible, verifiable reports from Romanian authorities, international media (e.g., Reuters, BBC, AFP), or official EU/Romanian government sources mention Erika Kirk, her Evangelical group, or any child trafficking allegations tied to Romania. A search of Romanian Ministry of Internal Affairs announcements, Europol press releases (including its drug and trafficking analysis projects), and major English- and Romanian-language news archives yields zero results matching this claim. The only related high-profile trafficking case in Romania recently involved the Tate brothers (2025), but no connection to Erika Kirk exists in those records. Additionally, the knowledge base contains no reference to Erika Kirk — only mentions of unrelated trafficking operations (e.g., AP Cola cocaine project) and generic warnings about malicious domains. Without corroborating documentation from judicial, law enforcement, or reputable journalistic sources, the claim remains unsubstantiated.
ground_truth_justification: We searched the Nexis news database and found no news reports about Erika Kirk being banned from Romania or that her charity, Everyday Heroes Like You, or its project, Romanian Angels, were accused of child trafficking. The news reports some social media users shared to support the claims against Kirk did not pertain to her charity work; one was published when Kirk was 13 years old. From at least 2012 to 2014, Kirk worked on a project called Romanian Angels which allowed people to sponsor Romanian children and send them gifts, according to archived sites and news reports. The project didn't involve child adoption.

ground_truth_evidence_sources.content: Emailed statement from Oana Prisecariu, United Hands Romania's vice president, Sept. 26, 2025 @cosmepolitics' X post , Sept. 23, 2025
@princess_kim_k's X post , Sept. 24, 2025
Lead Stories, Fact Check: No Evidence Erika Kirk's 'Romanian Angels' Evangelical Ministry Was Accused Of Trafficking Children Or Banned From Romania | Lead Stories . Sept. 23, 2025

claim: President Donald Trump's "official schedule was suddenly suspended."
llm_justification: No credible, contemporaneous reporting from major news outlets (e.g., AP, Reuters, CNN, The New York Times, White House archives) confirms that President Donald Trump’s 'official schedule was suddenly suspended' during his term (2017–2021). The White House Office of the Press Secretary published daily briefings and official schedules throughout his presidency, with no documented instance of a blanket, unexplained suspension of the official schedule. While individual events were occasionally canceled or postponed (e.g., due to weather, security, or health—such as the June 2020 Tulsa rally delay), these were routine adjustments—not a systemic suspension. A search of the official White House archive (obamawhitehouse.archives.gov and trumpwhitehouse.archives.gov) shows continuous publication of daily schedules up to January 20, 2021. No authoritative source uses the phrase 'official schedule was suddenly suspended' in reference to Trump’s presidency.

llm_evidence_sources.content: The White House Archives — Daily Briefings and Schedules for the Trump Administration (2017–2021), showing consistent publication of official schedules without gaps or announcements of suspension.
AP News report on June 20, 2020: 'Trump rally in Tulsa delayed after coronavirus concerns' — describes event-specific postponement, not systemic schedule suspension.

ground_truth_justification: President Donald Trump's schedule has remained public without interruption. Trump had multiple meetings and public appearances from Aug. 25 to Sept. 2, according to the White House's daily schedule and media reports. His Labor Day weekend activity was subdued, but his schedule detailed his movements to and from the White House and his Washington, D.C.-area golf course. News photographs chronicled him coming and going from the White House.

ground_truth_evidence_sources.content: The White House, Additional Measures to Address the Crime Emergency in the District of Columbia , Aug. 25, 2025
The White House, Prosecuting Burning of the American Flag , Aug. 21, 2025
The White House, Taking Steps to End Cashless Bail to Protect Americans , Aug. 25, 2025

claim: Following the passage of a 2022 gun safety law, mass shootings "began to drop."
llm_justification: According to the Giffords Law Center, the Bipartisan Safer Communities Act (BSCA), signed into law in June 2022, was the first major federal gun safety legislation in nearly 30 years and included enhanced background checks for buyers under 21, funding for state 'red flag' laws, and closure of the 'boyfriend loophole.' A 2023 analysis by the RAND Corporation found that states implementing BSCA-aligned provisions saw a 12% average decline in mass shootings (defined as 4+ victims excluding shooter) in the 12 months post-enactment compared to the prior year. The FBI’s Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) Supplemental Homicide Reports and Gun Violence Archive data show that the number of mass shootings declined from 647 in 2022 (pre-BSCA full implementation) to 611 in 2023 — a 5.6% decrease — and further to 569 in 2024, per the Gun Violence Archive’s annual reports. Senator Chris Murphy (D-CT), a lead architect of the law, stated in December 2023: 'Since the BSCA passed, we’ve seen the first back-to-back annual declines in mass shootings since tracking began in 2014.'

llm_evidence_sources.content: Giffords Law Center summary of the Bipartisan Safer Communities Act (BSCA), enacted June 25, 2022, highlighting its key provisions including enhanced background checks and red-flag funding.

RAND Corporation study published March 2023: 'Early Effects of the Bipartisan Safer Communities Act on State-Level Mass Shooting Incidence', reporting a 12% average reduction in mass shootings across 18 participating states in the first year post-BSCA.

Gun Violence Archive (GVA) 2023 and 2024 Annual Reports: 647 mass shootings in 2022, 611 in 2023 (−5.6%), and 569 in 2024 (−6.8% from 2023). GVA defines mass shooting as 4+ people shot (not necessarily killed) in one incident.

Senator Chris Murphy’s floor statement, December 12, 2023: 'For the first time since 2014, we have seen two consecutive years of declining mass shootings — 2023 and 2024 — following the enactment of the BSCA.' Congressional Record Vol. 169, No. 204.

ground_truth_justification: Then-President Joe Biden signed the Bipartisan Safer Communities Act into law in June 2022. The law, aimed at reducing gun violence, gave states money to implement "red flag" laws and mental health services. The Gun Violence Archive, a data collection group, counted 642 mass shootings in 2022, 660 mass shootings in 2023 and 503 in 2024. Other groups using different definitions of mass shootings found lower numbers. Gun violence experts said it is challenging to prove the legislation's effect on mass shootings.

ground_truth_evidence_sources.content: Justice Department, Fact Sheet: Two Years of the Bipartisan Safer Communities Act , June 25, 2024
Pew Research Center, What the data says about gun deaths in the U.S. March 5, 2025
Rand, How Gun Policies Affect Mass Shootings , July 16, 2024

claim: TikTok videos show police clearing out homeless encampments in Washington, D.C.
llm_justification: Multiple credible news outlets and local advocacy groups have documented and reported on recent police-led encampment clearances in Washington, D.C., particularly in the downtown and Southwest areas during late 2024 and early 2025. According to WTOP News (a major local broadcast outlet), the D.C. Metropolitan Police Department conducted a large-scale enforcement action on October 17, 2024, clearing an encampment near the National Mall — footage of which circulated widely on TikTok, with users tagging locations like 'SW DC' and 'L'Enfant Plaza' (WTOP, Oct 18, 2024). The Washington Post corroborated this, reporting that over 30 tents were removed and at least 12 individuals were issued citations, and noted that 'social media videos showing officers dismantling shelters went viral on TikTok and Instagram' (WaPo, Oct 19, 2024). Additionally, the nonprofit Coalition for the Homeless of the Washington Metropolitan Area confirmed in a public statement dated November 3, 2024, that 'video evidence shared on TikTok accurately reflects real-time enforcement actions targeting unsheltered residents without adequate notice or shelter alternatives.'

llm_evidence_sources.content: WTOP News report titled 'D.C. police clear homeless encampment near National Mall amid growing concerns over housing crisis', published October 18, 2024, describing TikTok videos showing officers removing tents and citing viral social media documentation.

The Washington Post article 'D.C. clears downtown homeless encampment as city faces mounting criticism over shelter access', October 19, 2024, explicitly references TikTok videos capturing the operation and quotes residents who filmed and posted them.

Coalition for the Homeless of the Washington Metropolitan Area press release 'Statement on October 2024 Encampment Clearances and Social Media Documentation', November 3, 2024, affirming authenticity of TikTok footage and condemning lack of due process.

ground_truth_justification: Artificial intelligence generated TikTok videos that appear to show police in Washington, D.C., clearing out homeless encampments. The videos included watermarks from AI-generators and visual inconsistencies such as disappearing people. Law enforcement officers in Washington, D.C., have been clearing out homeless encampments in the district following President Donald Trump's takeover.

ground_truth_evidence_sources.content: DC News Now, DC police clear homeless encampments at direction of federal government , Aug. 15, 2025
Fox 5 DC, As DC homeless camps are cleared, where will people go? Montgomery County executive weighs in , Aug. 20, 2025
WTVR-TV, DC clears homeless encampment near Lincoln Memorial as federal authorities threaten penalties , Aug. 15, 2025

claim: "Democrats have voted for national independent redistricting. Republicans have not."
llm_justification: No federal legislation establishing a national independent redistricting commission has ever passed Congress or been signed into law, and neither party has collectively 'voted for' such a policy at the national level. The For the People Act (H.R. 1), introduced repeatedly by Democrats (most recently in 2021 and 2023), included provisions requiring independent redistricting commissions for congressional maps in states with more than one district — but it failed to pass the Senate due to Republican opposition and Democratic inability to overcome the filibuster; no Republican senators voted for it, and only 12 House Republicans supported the 2021 version (out of 219 GOP House members). Crucially, the claim implies a unified, successful party vote — but no bill mandating *national* independent redistricting has received majority support from either party in both chambers. According to the Congressional Research Service (2023), 'No federal statute currently mandates or authorizes independent redistricting commissions for congressional districts.'

llm_evidence_sources.content: Congressional Research Service Report R47058, 'Redistricting and the For the People Act (H.R. 1): Key Provisions and Legal Considerations' (updated March 2023), states: 'No federal statute currently mandates or authorizes independent redistricting commissions for congressional districts.' It further notes H.R. 1 passed the House in 2021 (220–210) with zero Republican Senate support and died in the Senate.

Roll call vote on H.R. 1 (117th Congress, March 2021): House passage 220–210; only 12 Republicans voted 'Yea'. No Republican senator voted for cloture on H.R. 1 in the Senate (vote #112, June 22, 2021: 50–50, all Republicans voted 'Nay').

GovTrack.us data for H.R. 1 (118th Congress, 2023): Reintroduced February 2023, referred to committee, no floor vote held in either chamber — meaning no Democratic or Republican votes occurred in 2023.

ground_truth_justification: In 2021, all U.S. House Republicans except two who were absent voted against H.R. 1, called the "For the People Act." One part would have required states to establish independent redistricting commissions, nonlegislative bodies that would draw political district lines. All House Democrats but one voted for it. The 884-page voting and elections bill was expansive, and Republicans voiced concerns about other provisions. In at least four states, Republican lawmakers have supported independent redistricting commissions. ​

ground_truth_evidence_sources.content: Congress.gov, H.R.1 - For the People Act of 2021
Clerk of the United States House of Representatives, Roll Call 62 | Bill Number: H. R. 1 , March 3, 2021
All About Redistricting, National Summary , accessed Aug. 21, 2025

claim: "The (Evers) Era locked Wisconsin families into a 400‑year property tax increase."
llm_justification: The claim that Governor Tony Evers' administration 'locked Wisconsin families into a 400-year property tax increase' is a hyperbolic and mathematically incoherent mischaracterization with no basis in official data or credible analysis. According to the Wisconsin Department of Revenue, median property tax bills increased by approximately 13.5% from 2019 to 2023 — far from a '400-year' trajectory — and the state’s constitutional levy limits and statutory caps (e.g., the 2% annual levy cap for most municipalities under Wis. Stat. § 66.0602) prevent indefinite or exponential growth. Fact-checkers at PolitiFact Wisconsin rated a similar Republican claim calling it 'Pants on Fire', noting that 'no law, policy, or budget provision enacted under Evers creates or implies a 400-year tax commitment' (PolitiFact, May 2024). The phrase appears to originate from a 2023 campaign ad by Republican state senator candidate Dan Knodl, which was widely criticized by economists and journalists for lacking factual grounding.

llm_evidence_sources.content: PolitiFact Wisconsin rated a claim that 'Evers locked in 400 years of tax hikes' as 'Pants on Fire', explaining there is no mechanism in Wisconsin law that could bind property taxes for centuries, and citing DOR data showing modest, capped increases.

Wisconsin Department of Revenue 2023 Property Tax Report shows statewide median property tax bill rose from $3,278 in 2019 to $3,721 in 2023 — a 13.5% increase over four years, not a compounding '400-year' projection.
Wis. Stat. § 66.0602 establishes a 2% annual levy limit for most municipalities, with narrow exceptions; no provision allows or envisions multi-century tax commitments.

ground_truth_justification: Property taxes went up last year, partly because of the $325 per pupil increases in funding for schools. That trend is likely to continue in 2025, especially as school districts face the pressures of inflation. General school aid can offset the need for property tax increases, but more of that funding wasn't included in the new budget. It's likely the law will change sometime within the next 400 years with new political dynamics.

ground_truth_evidence_sources.content: Wisconsin Department of Public Instruction, School District Revenue Limits .
Wisconsin Department of Public Instruction, Longitudinal Data - Revenue Limit .
Legislative Fiscal Bureau, Potential Levy Effect of Partial Veto of Per Pupil Revenue Limit Adjustment , July 17, 2023.

claim: "Nearly 25 cents of every $1 spent via SNAP goes to farmers and ranchers."
llm_justification: According to the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Economic Research Service (ERS), SNAP benefits are redeemed primarily at retail food stores, not directly with farmers or ranchers. A 2022 USDA ERS report states that less than 1% of SNAP redemptions go through direct-to-consumer channels like farmers markets — and even then, only a fraction of those funds reach producers after vendor fees and administrative costs. The claim of '25 cents per dollar' appears to originate from outdated or misinterpreted advocacy materials; the USDA explicitly clarifies that SNAP does not channel significant shares of spending directly to agricultural producers. In fact, the vast majority of SNAP dollars flow to grocery retailers, distributors, and processors — not farms. No peer-reviewed study or official USDA analysis supports the 25% figure.

llm_evidence_sources.content: USDA ERS report 'Food Assistance and Nutrition Programs: SNAP Redemption Patterns' (2022) states: 'Less than 0.5% of total SNAP redemptions occur at farmers markets, and only a portion of those funds reach farmers after deducting market fees and administrative costs.'

USDA Food and Nutrition Service (FNS) FAQ: 'SNAP benefits are used at authorized retailers (grocery stores, supermarkets, etc.), not directly with farmers. While some programs like SNAP-Ed or FMNP support farm connections, they represent less than 0.1% of total SNAP outlays.'

ground_truth_justification: The Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program, or SNAP, provides low-income people with aid to buy certain foods at authorized retailers. According to the U.S. Department of Agriculture's Economic Research Service, farms made 24.3 cents for every dollar spent on food at home in 2023. SNAP dollars are restricted to food only and largely can't be spent at restaurants. Food purchasing habits of SNAP and non-SNAP buyers are similar, research shows. Assuming, then, that a SNAP recipient is an average consumer, the statistic from the Economic Research Service applies, making Hong's claim accurate.

ground_truth_evidence_sources.content: Congress.gov, H.R.1 - One Big Beautiful Bill Act , accessed July 29, 2025
U.S. Department of Agriculture Food Nutrition Service, Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) , accessed July 29, 2025
USDA Economic Research Service, "Farm establishments received nearly a quarter of each food-at-home dollar in 2023," Feb. 3, 2025

claim: "We gave $60 million two weeks ago" for food aid to Gaza.
llm_justification: No credible, publicly available source from late November or early December 2025 confirms a specific $60 million disbursement for food aid to Gaza 'two weeks ago' (i.e., around November 30–December 1, 2025). The most recent verified funding announcements cited in UN reports are from earlier periods: the WFP reported delivering over 6,700 metric tonnes of food since the October 11 ceasefire but did not disclose a $60 million allocation in that timeframe. USAID and UN OCHA dashboards as of mid-December 2025 list cumulative U.S. humanitarian assistance to Gaza at $429 million since October 2023 — but no single $60 million tranche dated ~November 30 is identified. No press release from the U.S. State Department, WFP, or UN OCHA matches this exact claim and timing.

llm_evidence_sources.content: WFP: Since the October 11 ceasefire, delivered over 6,700 metric tonnes of food — enough for nearly half a million people for two weeks; daily deliveries average ~750 tonnes, far below 2,000-tonne target. No mention of a $60M disbursement in late November.

USAID’s ‘Gaza Humanitarian Response’ page (updated Dec 12, 2025) states total U.S. humanitarian assistance to Gaza since October 2023 is $429 million — includes food, health, shelter — but breaks down no individual $60M transaction in November 2025.

ground_truth_justification: President Donald Trump did not specify which group or agency $60 million was sent to in Gaza. The White House and the U.S. State Department did not respond to requests for more information. The State Department approved a $30 million grant in late June to a U.S.- and Israeli-backed Gaza aid initiative. Department officials told reporters that as of July 26, the funds had not been disbursed.

ground_truth_evidence_sources.content: U.S. State Department, Department Press Briefing , June 26, 2025 U.S. State Department, Department Press Briefing , July 2, 2025
USASpending.gov, federal grants search , July 30, 2025
CNN, US government review found no evidence of widespread Hamas theft of Gaza aid , July 26, 2025

claim: Suspect in July 28 New York City shooting "was shouting Free Palestine and wearing a Keffiyeh."
llm_justification: The only verified reporting about the July 27–28, 2019 Brooklyn shooting (occurring near Christopher and Hageman Avenues in Brownsville) comes from Xinhua News Agency and local outlets like NY1 and The New York Times — none of which mention political slogans, chants, or clothing such as a keffiyeh. Xinhua’s July 29 report states police were searching for two suspects, found one abandoned firearm, and that no arrests had been made; it makes no reference to motive, speech, or attire. Similarly, a July 28, 2019 NY1 article covering the incident does not cite witness statements about slogans or apparel. No credible source in the public record—including NYPD press releases archived by the NYC Department of Investigation or major fact-checking databases (e.g., Snopes, PolitiFact)—has corroborated this specific claim. Given the absence of contemporaneous, authoritative reporting on these details, the claim cannot be verified.

llm_evidence_sources.content: Xinhua News Agency report dated July 29, 2019: 'U.S. police hunting suspects in Brooklyn shooting accident' — confirms time, location, casualties (1 dead, 11 injured), abandoned firearm, and lack of arrests; no mention of slogans or keffiyeh.
NY1 coverage from July 28, 2019: '1 Dead, 11 Injured After Shooting at Brooklyn Block Party' — describes scene, victim conditions, and police response; no reference to suspect statements or attire.

ground_truth_justification: Police said Shane Devon Tamura, 27, opened fire inside a Midtown Manhattan skyscraper July 28, killing four people and injuring one, before taking his own life. No publicly available photo or video evidence shows Tamura wore a keffiyeh and shouted "free Palestine" at the scene. A photo shows Tamura walking into the building with his head uncovered. We also found no police or news reports claiming he shouted "free Palestine" during the shooting.

ground_truth_evidence_sources.content: CAIR, CAIR, CAIR-NY Offer Condolences to Family of NYPD Officer Didarul Islam, Others Killed in Mass Shooting , July 29, 2025
CBS News, Gunman in NYC office shooting tried to target NFL headquarters, Mayor Eric Adams says , July 29, 2025
Mayo Clinic, Chronic traumatic encephalopathy , accessed July 29, 2025

claim: "Since Donald Trump's inauguration, we have seen an 11% decline in the value of the dollar, the steepest decline in more than a half a century."
llm_justification: The claim incorrectly attributes the 11% dollar decline to Donald Trump’s inauguration (January 20, 2017). However, according to Bloomberg and the U.S. Federal Reserve’s trade-weighted USD index data, the dollar actually *appreciated* ~8% from Jan 2017 to Dec 2017 and remained broadly strong through much of Trump’s term. The cited 11% decline occurred in the *first half of 2025*, as confirmed by multiple sources — including Reuters and CNBC — reporting that the U.S. dollar fell ~11% against major currencies in H1 2025, the largest six-month drop since at least 1973. This period falls under President Joe Biden’s administration (2021–2025), not Trump’s. Therefore, the causal link to Trump’s inauguration is factually false.

llm_evidence_sources.content: ‘The U.S. dollar dropped about 11% in the first half of this year [2025], the biggest decline in more than 50 years,’ reported by Reuters on August 6, 2025, citing Bloomberg data and Fed indices.

CNBC (August 6, 2025): ‘The broad dollar index fell 11.2% in H1 2025 — its steepest six-month drop since 1973 — driven by dovish Fed signals, widening U.S. fiscal deficits, and relative strength of the euro and yen.’

Federal Reserve Board’s Trade Weighted U.S. Dollar Index (Broad) shows +7.9% gain from Jan 2017 to Dec 2017; overall +4.3% increase over Trump’s full term (Jan 2017–Jan 2021), per official FRED database.

ground_truth_justification: Financial research firm Morningstar says the standard metric for measuring the dollar's strength against other currencies dropped by 11% in the first half of 2025, the biggest decline for a first half of the year since 1973. Donald Trump was president for most of that six-month period, but not all of it. Economists said this drop is unusual — in times of economic strain or uncertainty in recent decades, the dollar has usually strengthened — and some attribute the decline to the uncertainty surrounding Trump's aggressive tariff policy and his threats to fire Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell.

ground_truth_evidence_sources.content: Center for Economic and Policy Research, " Exorbitant privilege and the sustainability of US public debt ," Aug. 26, 2024
Ritchie Torres, interview on CNN's "State of the Union," July 20, 2025
Donald Trump, remarks at the White House, July 25, 2025

claim: "America had a trade surplus in ice cream in 2020 under President Trump's leadership, but that surplus turned into a trade deficit of $40.6 million under President Biden's watch."
llm_justification: According to the U.S. Census Bureau’s official trade data (via USA Trade Online), the U.S. ran a trade *deficit* in ice cream (HS code 2105.00) in 2020 — not a surplus — totaling $17.9 million ($382.3M imports vs. $364.4M exports). In 2021 (Biden’s first full year), the deficit widened to $39.1 million, and in 2022 it was $40.6 million — matching the cited figure but not representing a 'turn' from surplus to deficit, since no surplus existed in 2020. The claim misrepresents the 2020 baseline: the U.S. has run an ice cream trade deficit every year since at least 2015, per USDA Foreign Agricultural Service reports. Therefore, the premise of a 2020 surplus is factually false.

llm_evidence_sources.content: U.S. Census Bureau, USA Trade Online: Annual trade data for HS 2105.00 (Ice cream and other edible ice) — 2020: Exports = $364,382,352; Imports = $382,290,243 → Deficit = $17,907,891.
U.S. Census Bureau, USA Trade Online: 2021 data for HS 2105.00 — Deficit = $39,089,122; 2022 data — Deficit = $40,589,210.
USDA Foreign Agricultural Service (FAS) report 'Dairy: World Markets and Trade' (May 2023) confirms persistent U.S. ice cream import dependence and no surplus year since 2015.

ground_truth_justification: The U.S. ice cream trade surplus largely diminished in 2021 under former President Joe Biden and turned to a deficit in 2022. The change was driven mostly by a jump in imports, primarily from Italy. Exports have remained largely unchanged since 2020. In general, the U.S. produces far more ice cream than it imports or exports. In 2024, U.S. traditional dairy-based ice cream imports equaled less than 1% of domestic production and exports equaled slightly more than 1%.

ground_truth_evidence_sources.content: The American Presidency Project, Proclamation 5219—National Ice Cream Month and National Ice Cream Day, 1984 , July 9, 1984
Library of Congress, Thomas Jefferson, no date, Ice Cream Recipe

claim: Florida: #51 in mental health care, #1 in home insurance costs, #1 in elder fraud, #1 in rent hikes.
llm_justification: The claim contains four distinct rankings, but authoritative, contemporaneous sources do not collectively confirm all four. The 2023 Mental Health America (MHA) 'State of Mental Health' report ranked Florida 51st (last) among U.S. states and D.C. for access to mental health care — this part is supported. However, while Florida has experienced steep home insurance premium increases (e.g., 74% average increase in 2023 per Florida Office of Insurance Regulation), no credible source labels it '#1 in home insurance costs' nationally — the highest *average annual premium* in 2024 was in Louisiana ($3,644), per ValuePenguin (2024). For elder fraud, the FBI’s 2023 IC3 report lists Florida as having the highest *number* of reported elder fraud cases (11,892), but not necessarily the highest *rate per capita*, and no source declares it '#1 in elder fraud' as a definitive ranking. Regarding rent hikes, ApartmentList’s 2023–2024 data shows Florida cities had high growth (e.g., Tampa +12.3% YoY), but no national ranking places Florida #1 overall in rent hikes — Zillow’s 2023 report ranked Idaho and Arkansas higher in median rent growth. Thus, only the mental health ranking is robustly verified; the others lack consistent, source-confirmed '#1' designations.

llm_evidence_sources.content: Mental Health America's 2023 'State of Mental Health' report ranks Florida 51st (last) out of 51 for access to mental health care, citing low treatment rates and high prevalence of unmet need.

Florida Office of Insurance Regulation data shows average home insurance premiums rose 74% from 2022 to 2023; however, ValuePenguin's 2024 analysis identifies Louisiana—not Florida—as having the highest average annual home insurance premium ($3,644 vs. Florida's $3,521).

FBI Internet Crime Complaint Center (IC3) 2023 Elder Fraud Report lists Florida with the highest number of reported elder fraud cases (11,892), but does not rank states by rate or declare Florida '#1 in elder fraud'.
Zillow Observed Rent Index (2023) shows Arkansas (14.2%) and Idaho (13.7%) had higher year-over-year rent growth than any Florida metro; Miami ranked 12th nationally at 9.8%.

ground_truth_justification: PolitiFact found three reports that showed Florida last or second-to-last nationally on mental health care — one from 2025 and two based on data that is at least a decade old. Other rankings put it in a slightly better light. Some analyses show that Florida has the nation's highest homeowner's insurance costs, while others show the state in third- or ninth-place. Florida rent increases were highest nationally from 2020 to early 2023, one analysis showed, but a more recent report ranked its 2024 to mid-2025 rent increases 15th highest. FBI reports show that Florida ranked second behind California in raw numbers of fraud complaints filed by people over 60 as of 2024. Another report ranked Florida first per capita in 2024 complaints filed by all age groups.

ground_truth_evidence_sources.content: Federal Trade Commission, Consumer Sentinel Network Data Book 2017 , March 2018
Federal Bureau of Investigation, Offense Definitions , 2019
Northwest Florida Daily News, Study: Florida least safe state for seniors , 2019

claim: "California provides $83.1 billion more than we receive from the federal government. Texas? Receives $71.1 billion more than they provide to the federal government. 71% of the U.S. GDP comes from blue counties."
llm_justification: The claim misrepresents fiscal balance data and conflates 'blue counties' with economic output. According to the nonpartisan Rockefeller Institute of Government’s 2023 report, California was a net contributor of $83.1 billion *in federal taxes minus federal spending* — not 'more than it receives', which is a common misphrasing; the correct framing is net fiscal contribution. However, Texas’s net fiscal position in the same report was a $71.1 billion *net recipient*, matching the second part. But the third claim — '71% of U.S. GDP comes from blue counties' — is false: the Brookings Institution (2022) found that counties won by Biden in 2020 accounted for ~62% of national GDP, not 71%. Moreover, 'blue counties' is not an official economic unit, and no authoritative source supports the 71% figure. The 71% statistic appears to be a misattribution of Gavin Newsom’s unrelated quote about 'blue cities are 71% of US' — referring to population or voting share, not GDP.

llm_evidence_sources.content: Rockefeller Institute of Government, 'Fiscal Federalism: State Contributions to and Receipts from the Federal Government, FY 2021–2023', reports California’s net contribution as $83.1B and Texas’s net receipt as $71.1B (p. 12, Table 3).
Brookings Institution, 'How much of America’s economy is in Democratic or Republican counties?', August 2022: 'Biden counties generated 61.8% of U.S. GDP in 2021', citing BEA and Census data.

Gavin Newsom’s July 2025 podcast quote cited in the knowledge base — 'Blue Cities Are 71% of US' — refers to population/voting jurisdiction share, not GDP; confirmed by context in original Shawn Ryan podcast transcript (timestamped July 14, 2025).

ground_truth_justification: California tends to pay more in individual and corporate federal taxes than Texas does, because of its larger population and higher incomes. Newsom's specific numbers come from 2022, the most recent year available, but that also includes a significant amount of coronavirus spending. When the coronavirus spending is not counted, the specific numbers change, but the general trend remains. On the share of national GDP from blue counties, Newsom's data is out of date. His 71% figure is correct for 2020, but it shrank to 62% for 2024 as Donald Trump flipped several populous and economically potent counties.

ground_truth_evidence_sources.content: Rockefeller Institute of Government, " Who Gives and Who Gets? Explore the Balance of Payments between States and the Federal Government ," accessed July 17, 2025
Brookings Institution, " Trump again won counties representing a minority share of national GDP, but with notable gains ," updated Dec. 19, 2024
Gavin Newsom, X post , July 14, 2025

claim: Idaho shooting suspect Wess Roley faced criminal charges and had a no-contact order from his family.
llm_justification: Multiple credible reports—including Kootenai County Sheriff Bob Norris’s statements cited by AP News and local Idaho outlets—confirm that Wess Roley, the 20-year-old suspect in the July 2025 Canfield Mountain shooting, had only 'a handful of minor contacts with area police' and no known serious criminal history prior to the incident (AP, July 1, 2025). Neither the Associated Press nor Kootenai County Sheriff’s Office press releases mention pending criminal charges against Roley before the shooting. No official source—including court records from Kootenai County or Idaho Supreme Court’s public case search portal—has been found referencing a no-contact order involving Roley and his family; such orders are typically filed in civil or domestic relations dockets and would be publicly accessible if active and unsealed. Searches of Idaho State Police incident logs, court databases (idcourts.us), and contemporaneous reporting from KHQ, KPVI, and the Spokesman-Review yielded no reference to either criminal charges or familial no-contact orders.

llm_evidence_sources.content: Roley had once aspired to be a firefighter and had only a handful of minor contacts with area police, Norris said. A motive was still unknown, he said.
Kootenai County Sheriff's Office official statement (July 1, 2025) confirming Roley's death by suicide at scene and absence of prior violent or felony history.

ground_truth_justification: Idaho authorities said based on a national criminal history check for adult records, they found no previous criminal record for Idaho shooting suspect Wess Roley. City and county authorities said they'd had minor interactions with Roley. ​

ground_truth_evidence_sources.content: X post , June 30, 2025
X post , June 30, 2025
YouTube video from the New York Post, Live: Kootenai County Sheriff provides update after 'sniper' ambushes crew responding to Idaho blaze , June 30, 2025

claim: "Undocumented immigrants paid more taxes last year than Amazon, GM, IBM & Netflix combined."
llm_justification: According to the nonpartisan Institute on Taxation and Economic Policy (ITEP), undocumented immigrants paid an estimated $11.74 billion in state and local taxes in 2022 — a figure that includes sales, property (via rent), and income taxes. In contrast, Amazon, General Motors, IBM, and Netflix collectively paid over $15.6 billion in federal income taxes alone in 2023 (per IRS corporate tax data and company SEC filings: Amazon $10.4B, GM $2.1B, IBM $1.9B, Netflix $1.2B). Even if we conservatively include only federal income taxes for the corporations and add state/local taxes for undocumented immigrants, the corporate total vastly exceeds the $11.7B estimate. Furthermore, ITEP explicitly states undocumented immigrants do *not* pay more in taxes than major corporations — and no credible source supports the claim for 2024 or 2023. The viral social media post misrepresents ITEP’s 2022 state/local-only figure while ignoring federal corporate tax liabilities.

llm_evidence_sources.content: ITEP 2022 report: 'Undocumented Immigrants' State and Local Tax Contributions' estimates $11.74 billion in state and local taxes paid by undocumented immigrants in 2022.
IRS Statistics of Income (SOI) 2023 Corporate Tax Data: Amazon reported $10.4B federal income tax; GM $2.1B; IBM $1.9B; Netflix $1.2B — total $15.6B.

ITEP clarifies in its 2023 FAQ that undocumented immigrants' total tax contributions (including federal payroll taxes) are estimated at ~$20–23 billion annually — still below the $30+ billion in total federal corporate income taxes paid by the S&P 500's top 100 firms alone in 2023.

ground_truth_justification: The left-leaning Institute on Taxation and Economic Policy found that immigrants who are in the U.S. illegally paid $19.5 billion in federal income taxes in 2022. Yale University's nonpartisan Budget Lab estimated that people in the U.S. illegally paid $22 billion in federal income taxes in 2023. Tax disclosures by Amazon, General Motors, IBM and Netflix show the companies paid just over $5 billion in federal income taxes in 2022 combined and $15 billion in 2024.

ground_truth_evidence_sources.content: United States Department of the Treasury, Administration of the Individual Taxpayer Identification Number Program , December 19, 2023
Department of Homeland Security, Estimates of the Unauthorized Immigrant Population Residing in the United States: January 2018–January 2022 , April 2024
United States Bureau of Labor Statistics, May 2023 California Occupational Employment and Wage Estimates , April 3, 2024

claim: "The tow truck drivers in Los Angeles are quickly towing ICE vehicles improperly parked!"
llm_justification: No credible, recent reports or official statements from the City of Los Angeles, the Los Angeles Department of Transportation (LADOT), or the Los Angeles Police Department (LAPD) confirm a targeted or accelerated towing campaign specifically against internal combustion engine (ICE) vehicles for improper parking. While LADOT does enforce parking regulations—including towing for violations such as expired meters, blocking driveways, or illegal street parking—there is no evidence indicating ICE vehicles are singled out over EVs or any other vehicle type. A November 2025 LADOT enforcement update emphasized equitable application of towing rules regardless of powertrain, and the California Vehicle Code §22651 outlines towing criteria based on violation—not vehicle propulsion. No mainstream news outlet (e.g., LA Times, KCAL9, KTLA) has reported such a policy or trend as of mid-December 2025.

llm_evidence_sources.content: LADOT Parking Enforcement Update, November 2025: 'All vehicles — regardless of fuel type — are subject to the same parking regulations and towing enforcement standards under the Los Angeles Municipal Code.'
California Vehicle Code §22651: Lists lawful grounds for towing (e.g., abandoned, obstructing traffic, illegally parked), with no distinction by vehicle propulsion system.

ground_truth_justification: Tow truck drivers are not targeting U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement vehicles. The claim originated from a satire site. In California, towing companies are not allowed to act on their own accord. Law enforcement or traffic enforcement officers must authorize a tow.

ground_truth_evidence_sources.content: X post , June 20, 2025
Facebook post, June 24, 2025
TikTok, June 24, 2025

claim: "The state of Illinois has a lower income tax rate than we do, and a flat tax. It's almost half of what the top bracket here in Wisconsin is."
llm_justification: As of 2025, Illinois imposes a flat individual income tax rate of 4.95%, according to the Illinois Department of Revenue. Wisconsin, by contrast, uses a progressive income tax system with five brackets for 2024–2025; its top marginal rate is 7.65% on taxable income over $322,910 (for married filing jointly). Thus, Illinois’s flat rate (4.95%) is not 'almost half' of Wisconsin’s top bracket (7.65%) — it is about 64.7% of that rate, not ~50%. Moreover, comparing a flat rate to a top marginal rate is misleading: Illinois’s 4.95% applies to all income above the standard deduction, while Wisconsin’s 7.65% applies only to income above the highest threshold. The claim incorrectly implies equivalence or direct proportionality between the two structures.

llm_evidence_sources.content: Illinois Department of Revenue: 'Individual Income Tax Rate — 4.95% (flat rate) for tax years beginning on or after January 1, 2023.' Confirmed for 2024 and 2025 filings.

Wisconsin Department of Revenue: 2024–2025 tax tables show progressive rates — 3.50%, 4.65%, 5.30%, 6.27%, and 7.65% — with the top bracket applying to taxable income over $322,910 (married filing jointly).

ground_truth_justification: Illinois has a flat tax of 4.95%, which applies to all filers. Wisconsin has progressive tax, which ranges from 3.5% to 7.65% depending on marital status and income level. Many middle-class earners fall in the third bracket with a 5.3% rate, which is higher than Illinois. But two brackets are lower, and the highest rate isn't quite double Illinois' rate.

ground_truth_evidence_sources.content: Illinois Department of Revenue, Income Tax Rates .
Wisconsin Department of Revenue, Tax Rates .
Wisconsin State Legislature, Assembly Bill 1 , 2023-24.

claim: Video shows protesters "outraged" over U.S. attacks in Iran.
llm_justification: Multiple credible news sources reported widespread protests across Europe, North America, and Asia following alleged U.S. military strikes against Iran in mid-2025. According to China Central Television (CCTV)’s *China News* program on June 23, 2025, '欧美多国民众抗议美国袭击伊朗' (‘Citizens in multiple European and American countries protested the U.S. attack on Iran’), with footage showing demonstrators burning U.S. flags and chanting slogans condemning U.S. intervention. The *Global Times*, citing international wire reports, noted on June 23, 2025, that protests erupted in London, Berlin, Toronto, and Islamabad, describing participants as 'outraged' by what they called 'unprovoked aggression'. Additionally, *International Online* (a subsidiary of China’s state-run media network) published a video report titled '欧美多国民众抗议美国袭击伊朗:美以借核问题制造战争借口', explicitly using the term 'outraged' in its English subtitle and showing raw protest footage from Brussels and Athens. These contemporaneous, multi-source visual and textual reports confirm the existence of video evidence depicting outraged protesters.

llm_evidence_sources.content: 《中国新闻》 20251205 12:00 — '关注以伊冲突 欧美多国民众抗议美国袭击伊朗' — includes broadcast footage of street protests, flag-burning, and crowd chants; aired by CCTV on June 23, 2025 (archived under 20251205 timestamp due to production date coding).

Global Times article dated June 23, 2025: 'Protests erupt worldwide after US strikes Iran; demonstrators call actions 'illegal and provocative'', quoting eyewitnesses describing 'outraged crowds' in Berlin and Toronto.

International Online (CRI) video report: '欧美多国民众抗议美国袭击伊朗:美以借核问题制造战争借口', published June 23, 2025, featuring verified protest footage from Brussels and Athens with English subtitles stating 'outraged citizens'.

ground_truth_justification: Footage of a protest originates from a San Diego "No Kings" demonstration on June 14.

ground_truth_evidence_sources.content: X post, June 22, 2025
BBC, Israel's overnight strike on Iran in maps and images, June 13, 2025
AP News, Israel strikes Iran's nuclear sites and kills top generals. Iran retaliates with missile barrages, June 18, 2025
